summary:
Dabi is back, and if Hawks didn’t know better, he would say that the villain's expression looks confused. Dabi’s hand gestures around his own scarred mouth, where a smirk is slowly growing.

 

“You’ve been busy,” he greets, and at first Hawks doesn’t even know what he’s talking about, but he knows that it’s not the impressive stack of completed paperwork on his desk. Tentatively, he raises his own fingers to his mouth and rubs lightly before looking down at them. They’re a bright red, too artificial to be blood, but his stomach still lurches at the sight. Hawks almost wishes that it was blood.

 

“So, what, am I too ugly for ya? There ain’t no way that you’re straight,” Dabi’s smiling like a cat, the wide smile making the staples in his skin pull, and it’s just unsettling enough, and Hawks is already at the end of his rope enough to just tell someone.

 

“I couldn’t move.”

 

Obviously, that was not the response that Dabi was expecting.

Or: Hawks works through some stuff and Dabi calls him a bitch (said softly, with love) as he does it.

text:
The first time it happens, Hawks still lives with his parents, and he’s seven years old.
 
It’s night time, and he’s really not supposed to be up, but neither was anyone else. Sometimes, if she feels up to it and she’s sober, very rarely, his mom will remember that he’s there, that he’s her son, and she’ll come read him a story. His dad doesn’t do it, doesn’t seem to care as much, but it’s still nice. Having the attention of one of his parents makes his chest feel full and bright, like his heart has been replaced with the sun. His mother comes in, and she’s not sober but that’s all right, she’s here-
 
She reads him a story.
 
She tucks him in, her movements sloppier than usual and she has to steady herself on his shoulder more than once.
 
And she kisses him.
 
Her mouth is a lot bigger than his, she’s a lot bigger than him in general, and he can taste the alcohol on her breath before she lets go and leans back from him. It lasts less than a second, but he feels something tight curl in his chest and stay there. His mother doesn’t seem to feel it. In a rare moment of affection, one that he usually has to fight tooth and nail for, she smiles down at him, like he’s made her really happy. Her face lights up just like his does sometimes, and he can feel a smile pulling through his confusion at the sight. There’s nothing wrong about it, he tells himself after she’s long gone and he’s still awake. It’s just a kiss, but- it feels different from the kisses he sometimes gets from his dad. His dad kisses his forehead, his nose, the top of his head, even his cheek. It takes less than a second for Keigo to decide that he likes those kisses better. But he can’t be ungrateful, not if he still wants his mom to love him. 
 
Later, when he goes to brush his teeth again because he can still taste the alcohol, he sees it. Keigo is barely tall enough to see his reflection in the dirty bathroom mirror, he can’t even see his chin, but he can see the smear of his mom’s bright red lipstick across his lips. He tries to scrub it off, his sharp talons carefully kept away from his skin, but it only smears the red until it leaves pink stains across his face. It’s just a kiss, and Keigo’s not gonna complain just because he doesn’t like where his goodnight kisses are, because they can be taken away just like everything else.
 
So he never says anything, and she keeps coming back.
 
And almost every night, unless he’s been bad, he gets a kiss.
 
He learns to cherish them, to want them, but the thing in his chest never really disappears.
 
 
When the Hero Public Safety Commission takes him in, Hawks just kind of assumes that those kinds of kisses will stop; his mom isn’t here, and all of the workers are too professional to be giving him ‘good boy’ kisses. Then, as a mandatory part of his new training, Keigo- Hawks, he’s Hawks now-
 
Hawks has to learn CPR.
 
The person teaching him, a man with some sort of animal quirk, is his teacher. He watches Hawks practice on the dummy very closely, correcting his compressions and form. When it’s time for the part where he pushes air into the dummy’s lungs, his trainer stops him and says that Hawks would learn better with a real person who has real lungs, and he replaces the dummy. Hawks tries to focus, to do it right, but he feels too nervous, and his trainer offers to show him how to do it. When he quickly accepts, wanting to do well, he gets a smile for his eagerness.
 
Hawks is the practice dummy this time, and he does choke when the man’s tongue is shoved into his mouth.
 
When his trainer stops, seeming satisfied with today’s lesson, he sends Hawks a smile just like his mother used to. On reflex, Hawks smiles back.
 
 
Years later, Hawks has a ‘hey, wait a minute’ moment where he remembers and only freaks out a little bit. He spends what feels like hours staring up at his ceiling, feeling too wound up to even move, like if he tries he’ll snap like a cheap piece of plastic that got a barbell chucked at it. Everything is fine because it has to be, heroes don’t get taken advantage of, and he wasn’t. It was just a kiss, and yeah, he was young, but it had been for training, right? It was to make him a better hero. And even if it was more, if it was less than innocent, what could he really do about it?
 
Hawks had never said yes, but he hadn’t said no either.
 
Something about it still doesn’t sit right with him, weighing on his mind every time he was brought into a room that even looked a little bit like the one with the CPR training, but it’s easily ignored once his actual hero training starts. He doesn’t think of it again, pushing it deep into the ‘fuck this shit I’m not dealing with it’ part of his brain and ignores the thing that screams at him to connect the dots.
 
 
One of his new Handlers, only a few years older than his own seventeen years, calls him handsome and he tries not to glow under the praise. He tells her that she’s pretty, like he was taught to when he was learning about social interaction, and she smiles that specific smile. The sight of it makes the light feeling drop from his chest on sight, and it only drops further when she puts her hands on his shoulders and pulls him in closer. 
 
 
Hawks is twenty two now, and he still doesn’t think much of it. But sometimes, it’s hard, especially when he’s been dragged out to go drinking with a few other pro heroes for publicity reasons.
 
He feels too dressed up, put on display with his nice jacket and a tie that he had loosened the second he’d left for this thing. It’s not a suit event, thank the gods, but it’s certainly a nicer thing and he has to represent well.
 
The night starts off alright, with Hawks having found (and attached himself to) Rumi, who’s wearing a floor length dress and looking gorgeous in it. They quickly relocate to the bar, which is still crowded, but it has more order to it, and claim stools right next to each other. He’s not antisocial, he can meet and greet fans with the best of them, which he is, but crowds are horrible for his stupid quirk. Not only does his stupid bird brain want to be up high where he can see everyone, which isn’t going to happen inside a crowded one-story building, but his wings ache in overstimulation. He can feel every vibration, every bass drop and laugh, and it had made his wings twitch the second that he’d walked through the door and it’s only gotten worse the longer he stays. It feels like his feathers are crawling with ants, and he’s immediately reminded why he hates these things with a passion that he always abandons when the commission adds incentive. 
 
Incentive could be anything from a smaller paycheck to an extra round of training, and it’s best to avoid it all together. 
 
Someone tries to sneakily pet his wings for the fourth time in seventeen minutes and Hawks resists the urge to ‘accidentally’ slap them with it. Rumi must see the look of despair on his face, because she laughs at him and throws a hard punch at his arm. “C'mon Hawks. Don’t be such a chicken. Loosen up!” Hawks slowly looks her up and down (the dress does her justice, really, but the plunging neckline makes him wonder how things don’t just… pop out)  before giving her his best sex look, “I’m always loose for you, baby,” he purrs, leaning in close and batting his eyes exaggeratedly. “Bottom,” Rumi scoffs with a mock-disgusted look, shoving him away but making sure that he doesn’t hit anyone behind him. They stare at each other and manage to make it only a few seconds before they’re cackling loud enough that even Present Mic hears them and looks mildly impressed with their volume. “Really though,” she throws an arm around his shoulder, “chill out before someone vibe checks you.”
 
“That was your idea,” Hawks accuses dramatically, pointing an accusing finger at her. Rumi cackles again.
 
“Yeah, but did you see the scum’s face-” her hand, which he thinks represents him, shoots through the air and slams onto the bar as she screeches, “vibe check!” and falls into a laughing mess. Hawks remembers the look of confused horror right before he landed on the criminal and starts to laugh at it himself because yeah, that was a good day. The commission hadn’t been thrilled about it, but they’d grudgingly calmed down after the stunt got posted on Tiktok and Hawks became more popular with the kids. They had said that it was ‘acceptable’, which Hawks took as an encore for a repeat performance at any point. While Rumi orders for both of them, he considers making ‘vibe check’ an official attack, just to see if the commission would let him.
 
A drink is placed in front of him, something sweet and girly looking with a rose accent piece that he rolls his eyes at because he knows that it doesn’t come with the drink. Rumi takes one look and slaps a hand over her mouth to smother her giggles, “I didn’t think that he’d do it, holy shit this is great! I’m gonna keep doing it and asking for random shit, watch.” 
 
It tells him exactly who the rose is from, who it was really meant for, and that there’s gonna be a lot more.
 
In short, Hawks isn’t leaving this event sober.
 
“I hate you,” Hawks sulks, throwing the rose, unfortunately de-thorned, at her. Instead of looking insulted, Rumi glows even brighter with mischief, “I bet these tits can get me anything I want,” she boasts before adjusting her dress so that it sits even lower (Hawks really wonders how nothing has happened) and leaning over the bar to order more drinks.
 
It works.
 
By the time that the bartender finally stops staring at Rumi’s chest and catches on, they have quite the collection of flowers and other small things, and Eraserhead has shown up and is staring at them with exasperation clear on his face as Mic tries not to laugh. “We’re sharing,” Hawks defends, offering them a spiraling piece of chocolate that had been on a drink. Eraserhead swats Mic’s hand away when it reaches for the chocolate, making the grown man and teacher pout like a child. Hawks offers him a bright yellow worm on a string instead, which doesn’t get swatted away.
 
“Who’re ya sharing with?” Mic asks, weaving the glorified fluffed up yarn in between his fingers with a level of inattention to things around him that gives blondes a bad reputation.
 
Hawks sends them double finger guns and slaps on his best smile, “you guys!”
 
Eraserhead looks like he’d rather be anywhere but here, but he does help Hawks and Mic carry all of the drinks back to an empty booth. Rumi scoops up all of the little accent pieces and uses the dress of her skirt as a sort of pouch to carry them in. It works, really well, actually, but it brings the length up from the floor to mid-thigh, getting her some looks (and if feathers knock glasses out of hands when eyes follow her too closely, Hawks has nothing to do with it). Somehow, over the collection of very girly but shockingly weak drinks, they get to the subject of parents. Hawks thinks that it had something to do with Mic teasing Eraser about adopting his class, which Rumi had laughed uproariously at and called them the ‘dads of UA’, and things had snowballed so badly that the end result wasn’t even a ball. This was proven seconds later, when everything went pear shaped after Mic had admitted that his parents weren’t great about his quirk when he was a kid. Rumi had quickly swapped to weird shit her parents had done before, getting a laugh out of Mic when she complained about the lipstick stains that had always been on her forehead as a kid, to the extent that a classmate had asked if it was a birthmark. Hawks winces in sympathy at the story before contributing to the ‘make Mic laugh’ fund.
 
“I get you, my mom used to do full on mouth kisses!” He makes an exaggerated ‘yuck’ face that everyone but Eraser laughs at. Rumi launches into a story, dragging Mic with her as she gestures and practically shouts her tale. Hawks watches her, watches Mic as the man becomes loud at something that she’s said. Something in Hawks’ chest grows heavy at the memories he's unintentionally stirred up, and he can feel his smile become less and less genuine. The teacher notices.
 
“That’s odd,” he comments, careful enough to not be loud enough to pull Rumi and Mic’s attention.
 
“The kissing thing? Not really,” Hawks says, swirling the new drink that was just placed in front of him, despite the numerous half full ones on the table. The skeptical eyebrow he gets in reply makes him nervous, like he’s said something that’s weird.
 
 “That's just how some parents are,” Hawks laughs, trying to quell his inner panic because what the absolute fuck. Aizawa nods his head like he understands, but the guy is a pro who teaches kids who probably try to bullshit him all the time, so him nodding could mean anything really. Hawks can read people pretty well, he’s infiltrating the league after all (so what if he’s not selling them out, he can still read them well enough to know that Shigaraki hates Disney and will try to disintegrate any disk that comes too close to him), and he gets the gut feeling that Eraser doesn’t believe him at all but is willing to drop it. Hawks knocks back part of the drink in his hand, almost choking at the sickly sweet taste and the unexpected bubbles in it. 
 
He rejoins the story right as Rumi screams “vibe check!” and slams her hand into the table for emphasis. Hawks laughs even harder than he did the first time, and Eraser actually has to activate his quirk on Mic, who’s losing his shit and making eardrums burst because of it. Unable to find the words he wants, Hawks smiles widely and nods fast enough that he gets a little dizzy. He’s reaching for a drink before it even registers that he’s really thirsty. The drink, something iced and yellow that tastes like mango, does nothing for his suddenly dry throat as he chugs it. Something in his mind clicks as he’s drinking, and he almost spits the drink out onto the nice table. The mango drink, a sugary monstrosity, is less sweet than what is supposedly champagne or something.
 
How his weird champagne drink could’ve been roofied in a room full of heroes, he has no idea, but it happened and the effects are hitting him hard. You gotta have balls of steel to pull this kinda shit, Hawks thinks blearily as he tries not to fall over while sitting down. Yeah, he’d land in Rumi’s lap, but a lot of papers already think that they’re dating, which is gross and he’s not gonna willingly add fuel to that fire. He has a few options right now, all of them half-formed and not nearly as appealing as staying here and drinking mango. It’s either stay for a bit so it’s not suspicious and don’t say anything and hope that he doesn’t eat shit the second he tries to stand, tell someone and ruin the event for everyone and forever be the hero that someone roofied at a fucking hero party, or hope that he can leave without causing a scene and keep his dignity in tact. Honestly, he’ll take his chances outside, even if the blue worm on a string that's tied to the mango drink's stem looks really fun to play with. Hawks reaches for the drink in front of him, intent to finish it despite the way that the world is blurry and his mind is whispering for him not to, that it’s a horrible idea. His throat is so dry that it almost burns.




Hawks picks up the drink in front of him and knocks it back before immediately pulling back from it to stare at the empty glass in wonder. His tongue tingles like he’s been holding pop rocks in his mouth for hours.
 
“There’s bubbles,” he says in awe, trying to move his head low enough to see them as they cling to what little liquid is left in the cup. His wings are fluffed up in childish happiness, and his fingers itch to hold the cup closer. Eraser gives him an odd look, like he’s trying to puzzle something out like the puzzle-man that he is. He’s weird; you couldn’t pay Hawks to watch kids with quirks, especially teenagers. His feathers are flammable.
 
His wings are completely lax on his back, their tips dusting the floor slightly. As he’s plotting his escape from the chair, they swish back and forth a little bit, like they’re trying to fold against his back but they can’t. He’s saved from having to stand alone when Rumi grabs him, her grip being the only thing keeping him balanced as she suddenly hauls him up with her. A rush passes through his head and he startles but laughs at the spinning vision that he gets as he collapses into Rumi’s side. “Hawks, you’re wasted!” she laughs, tapping at his flushed face while he tries to tell if the world is supposed to move like that. He smiles at her, waving to Mic and Eraser as he’s pulled away from the table. They watch him go, Eraser looking from him to the bubbly drink's empty cup and narrowing his eyes.
 
 On the way out, some guy falls into him with a small laugh, his hands landing on Hawks’ hip and waist as he tries to steady himself. Hawks knows that this man isn't drunk, he's a horrible actor, but he helps to steady him anyway, because he's a hero. When the man looks up, he smiles like a cat, and Hawks tries not to flail as one hand leaves only to run through his feathers. Despite trying not to make a noise, he whines at the touch; it’s painful, an overload of sensation to his wired body, but he can’t find it in himself to ask the man to stop. He sends Hawks that look, the one that makes the hero’s skin crawl, and Hawks paws at Rumi as she keeps going, dragging two people behind her. Rumi, ever the supportive best friend, turns and sees him, whistles and lets him go, which is absolutely not what he wanted. “Damn Hawks, get it! I’ll get an Uber,” she calls, already turning to walk away, to leave him here.
 
Hands grab his shoulders, holding him in place, before one glides up to the back of his head and a hot mouth closes over his just like one had when he was younger. The familiar taste of alcohol makes him feel vaguely sick, like his body’s trying to reject it but it doesn’t know how to. Hawks squirms, trying to get away, but everything is so nice right now, and he can’t connect to his body to ask why it wants to get away from the kiss. There’s nothing wrong with it, it’s not bad-
 
 Hands roughly separate them, before carefully passing Hawks off to yet another set of hands, and his body immediately relaxes into the new hold, happy to be away from the handsy guy. Blonde hair tickles his face, and he laughs, imagining it as a worm on a string wig. “Shouta thinks you’re drugged,” a voice says to him. Realizing who had saved him, Hawks feels a rush of relief flow through him. “Puzzle man!” he cheers, drawing a laugh from Mic. Hawks wonders at the vibration of it, feeling it hit his feathers and shoot up his spine. He glances back at Eraser and sees him laying into the young hero, sounding stern and bored at the same time. The guy looks thoroughly chastised, but he protests, “he was into it! Besides, he wasn't sayin' no.”
 
Eraser lifts an unimpressed eyebrow that the hero wilts under the sheer power of, "what did you give him?"
 
The guy, who Hawks now notices is wearing a server's costume, pales so quickly that he almost matches his white shirt.
 
“It’s true, ya know,” Hawks frowns, wiggling in Mic’s hold as Eraser walks back over. Mic hums in question, distracted and more concerned with the underground hero’s return than the puddle-of-hero’s mumbles. He still stiffens like he’s been electrocuted when the Hawks shifts in his arms and whispers to him like it’s a secret,
 
“I didn’ say no, so ‘ts ‘kay.”
 
Rumi comes back and takes one look at him before taking him from Mic, who looks like he wants to never let go. Eraser seems to share the sentiment, but they still allow Rumi to take him. Around them, the party is still in full swing, and the music’s sheer volume makes him paw at his ears and he can’t imagine how his friend feels. She’s got bunny ears. 
 
When Hawks reaches for her ears she threatens to bite him and he frowns at her but lowers his hand.
 
 
A week later, pictures are circling every platform that can hold them, and all of them imply a relationship between the random guy and Hawks.
 
The pictures in question are a nightmare for him, because his phone is blowing up with messages from Rumi and his Handler, both having very different opinions about it for vastly different reasons.
 
Rumi is happy that Hawks is ‘getting some’ and ‘leaving the closet’ and is offering to throw him a party, but is also laughing about Eraser and Mic scaring the guy off.
 
Present Mic, who must have gotten his number from her, asks how he’s doing.
 
Eraserhead wants to talk to him.
 
Dabi calls him once and only once, but Hawks lets the phone ring until it stops.
 
His Handler just tells him that he’s due for more training that wasn’t on his schedule, and to call her at his earliest convenience. His fingers fumble as he dials her number and waits for her to pick up.
 
“Hawks,” she greets, her voice sounding sharp even over the phone. “I’m going to send you something, and you are going to look at it right now and be quiet while I tell you what’s going to happen."
 
He nods, even though she can’t see him, and pulls out a tablet so that he can see what she sends and not hang up. Immediately, he gets a notification from his Handler, a link that makes his stomach drop through the floor.
 
“You are going to look at these, and you are going to know what you did wrong and do better,” his Handler drones on as he hesitantly taps on the link. There's a terrifying moment while everything loads, and there’s a lot of it. Picture after picture, almost every single one containing him being blatantly groped at a hero party by someone who is obviously not a hero while Hawks himself looks drunk as fuck and very unhappy. Hawks doesn’t stare at them for too long, instead scrolling through what people are saying.
He’s tagged in a tweet that calls him ‘easy’, and his wings twitch at the sight of it as he tries not to shake. His Handler continues to drone on, and Hawks wants to scream that he did nothing wrong, that he’d been roofied and then grabbed, but he knows that she won’t want to hear it, that she’ll consider it a weakness. So he smiles, and rubs the back of his neck sheepishly and gives her a show as he apologizes and promises not to let it happen again. He uses his best embarrassed tone, making sure that the phone does it justice, and excuses himself.
 
This wouldn’t really be a problem; usually, everyone is more worried about the rise in crime rate than they are about what happens to tipsy (drugged) heroes. But the pictures are in every paper. Every. Paper.
 
The headline is usually something along the lines of ‘HOTTEST HERO AND PARTY HOOK-UP CAUGHT’ or something equally long and painful to say.
 
And Hawks knows that this is going to be a problem.
 
 
A week ago, if someone had told Hawks that the League of Villains read the newspaper, he would have laughed and assumed that it was Kurogiri who demanded that they get it each time it was printed, because he can’t see any of the others caring enough about it.
 
It’s not that Hawks had assumed that Shigaraki couldn’t read, it was just hard to imagine that reading lessons fit in with his ‘how to be evil’ lessons as a kid. He doesn’t have an excuse for the rest of them, he just never got past Shigaraki.
 
So when he shows up to the league because Twice wanted more mochi and somehow he was their sugar daddy, he isn’t expecting to see Toga cutting out pictures from the paper like a grandmother. Yeah, if they do something particularly impressive it gets cut out and framed like a certificate of villainy, but the league hasn't made a major move like that in a while. On reflex, he tries to remember if one of those students that she likes, a boy and a girl who she complains are dating each other and not her, got into enough trouble to be in the paper recently. Honestly, Hawks wouldn’t bat an eye if they had. As far as he's concerned, going to UA is a wild ride and would shave years off of your life, and he isn’t going to step foot inside unless he has to. He’s about to call out to her and hand off the bag before leaving, he’s got stuff to do, but he stops short.
 
Toga holds up a picture, obviously cut out of a newspaper, and it’s a closeup of his face pressed into the other guy’s face, from the night of the hero gathering thing. Hawks stares at it, at the placement of a hand buried in his wing and digging into his waist, and he can almost feel the hands still touching him. He shakes out his wings to get rid of the feeling, the rustle causing Toga to turn around and smile at him before turning back to her project. She pulls up a second one, this one on printer paper, like she’d zoomed in and printed it out. The second one is zoomed in on Hawks face, and he looks dazed and mildly panicked; it’s a horrible photo, and he can’t believe that they actually published it because he looks so uncomfortable that he has to suppress his wince of embarrassment. Toga taps on it, “you look... ugly, Hawks. And not cute,” she says with a happy tone that steadily drops as she keeps going. Dabi, who had joined them at just the right moment, snorts at the bluntness. Hawks wants to ask how he should look in the photo, how he should have responded to the situation. How she would have handled it if she couldn’t fight the guy.
 
 Instead of asking, he stays quiet.
 
Toga leans in close, not stopping when Hawks leans back, and presses her small nose into his neck before breathing deeply and holy shit she’s smelling him. She’s like a police dog and Dabi, who hasn’t made a move to stop her, is her human partner. His pulse pounds in his ears, and he’s sure that she can hear it, can feel it against the tip of her nose as he fights the urge to push her out of his space. When she breathes out, war air hitting his neck in the worst way possible, he flinches.




“You’re not in love,” Toga declares before leaning back and looking confused, “so why?”
 
 Dabi stares at him, but Hawks ignores him in favor of being reunited with his personal space and trying to calm his racing heart. He jumps at the question, willing to do anything to put her pressing him into a wall and getting too close for comfort behind him.
 
“Why what? Why am I kissing him in the picture or why don’t I like him?” Hawks asks, raising an eyebrow at her. She considers him with a seriousness that he didn’t think she could have before shrugging, “both.”
 
“It’s a party thing,” he explains, not looking her in the eye, “I was drunk, he was... there, and I guess that he thought I was into it,” Toga tilts her head at him and he hurries to tack on a quick, “I wasn’t.”
 
Dabi leaves the room, looking like he’s annoyed by Hawks’ very existence, and he feels his wings wilt a little bit on his back, drooping until their tips dust the floor. Most times, he doesn’t even know what he did, and this is one of those times. Hawks makes sure that his smile stays firmly on his face.
 
“Does he know that?” Toga continues to press, scratching at the other hero's picture until she rips a hole through his face. Hawks stares at his still intact face in the picture and wonders if he does, if the guy knew about the roofie thing or if he was just a horny party goer. It’s not like it would matter if the guy knew; Hawks is still kinda stuck in this situation because of him. Instead of a real answer, or a lie because he doesn’t actually have a real answer, he just shrugs at her.
 
“Not sure. I’ll ask the next time I see him.”
 
He’s gonna avoid the guy like the plague if he sees him, but she doesn’t need to know that.
 
 
Hawks gets an invitation to go to UA for some sort of Sexual Assault PSA, not as a speaker, oh no, but as an attendee. It’s phrased, very gently, as ‘chaperone’ but, as much as class 1-A needs more supervision on the best days, Hawks is positive that the only productive thing he’d be doing is practicing his poker face and holding a box of tissues for the students, that he absolutely will not need to use as well because he’s shoved all that behind him.
 
And the things that the invitation alone implies are things that he leaves boxed away somewhere in his mind under six feet of dirt and seven feet of cement, never to be seen again, but they slowly try to crawl out. Like it’s a zombie movie and every kiss he’s ever had is trying to come back from the grave and cut off his breathing, choking him every time he’s reminded of them. He forcefully shoves them back down, tying weights to their ankles in the form of reminding himself why he shouldn’t care- why he can’t care. Technically speaking, he’s not Keigo anymore, so anything from then, from his mother, is kicked off of the ‘freak out about it’ list and into the goddamned sun. His trainer was teaching him CPR, which is important, and which Hawks did learn, so that one can also be forgotten. His Handler, the one who used to watch over him, was around his age, so it doesn’t count. Maybe she tripped, the world may never know.
 
Besides, there’s nothing that can be done about it now, even if it was a whole thing, which it isn't.

"We wouldn't hate you for being hurt, Hawks, we'd hate them for doing it," Spinner says, and Hawks didn't know that it was something that he needed to hear until it was said.
 
"They've accepted you as one their own! What idiots!" Twice chimes in, popping up from behind Toga, who smiles at him.
 
"Oh," he says, slightly touched and very surprised that he's not being thrown out on his ass. As everyone decides that the show is over and slowly go back to what they were doing before, Dabi snorts at him, copying him just like he had earlier.
 
"Yeah, 'oh'."
 
Scarred arms wrap around him from behind, careful to avoid brushing any part of his shoulder or making him feel trapped, and pull him to Dabi's side on the couch. The position forces his wings to fan out, and Toga is immediately petting them roughly. Hawks finds that he doesn't mind, especially when Dabi keeps an arm around him. His duffel bag is shoved into his hands, still sad-looking, but it brings him no small amount of comfort to hold it. Dabi's hand taps on his arm to get his attention before resting lightly on his neck, still steering away from his shoulder. Hawks appreciates it, leaning closer and tentatively looking up at the villain. Then his big mouth opens and ruins it.
 
"Is this a friendly cuddle session, or-"
 
Dabi kisses him and his wings jerk and fluff out in surprise as he crushes his duffel bag in his grip. When he pulls back, Hawks stares at him dazedly, question answered, and flops back into the villain's arms. Toga's hands quickly settle back into his feathers. They sit there for what feels like hours, Hawks slowly melting into the heat that Dabi is putting off, still loosely holding his duffel bag, before Hawks finally asks.
 
"What happens after this?" he whispers, staying quiet so he doesn't disturb the peace too much. Dabi doesn't answer, and Hawks is about the just assume that he's asleep, when he feels the villain sigh.
 
"I think," Dabi nudges him to get his attention as they sit there, looking down at him, "that whatever happens, you're gonna be fine."
